agencies.name: Department of Housing Preservation and Development
Department of Consumer and Worker Protection

specific_request_instructions.text:
If you are looking to report a crime, please call 911 or your local precinct.

The CCRB does not have direct access to NYPD records. If the NYPD records you are seeking, such as a report of a crime or body-worn camera footage, are not part of a CCRB investigation, you will need to request them from the NYPD. You can use this portal and select the New York City Police Department (NYPD) from the dropdown menu or you can find more information here: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/nypd/services/law-enforcement/record-requests.page

Officer CCRB Histories can be found here: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/ccrb/policy/MOS-records.page

Additional statistical information about complaints can be found here: https://data.cityofnewyork.us/browse?Dataset-Information_Agency=Civilian+Complaint+Review+Board+%28CCRB%29&q=&sortBy=relevance

Many CCRB closing reports are available here: https://www.nyc.gov/site/ccrb/complaints/closing-reports.page

Requests for Child Protective Investigation Records should be directed to:

ACS Records and Compliance Unit

Please submit a written, notarized request that includes the names, dates of birth, and last known address/ borough for individuals who may have been involved in the Child Protective Investigation. Please include a mailing address where any records you are entitled to can be sent. This written and notarized request may be sent by fax to the Records and Compliance Unit at fax (212) 341-0726 or by Mail to The New York City Administration for Children’s Services, Records & Compliance Unit, 150 William Street, 5th Floor, New York, NY 10038. (Do Not submit a Health Information Privacy and Portability Act “HIPPA” Form as ACS is not a HIPPA entity.)


Requests for Foster Care Records should be directed to:

Please direct Foster Care Record Requests to the specific Foster Care Agency that provided services to your family. Typically, ACS does not maintain foster care records. If the Foster Care agency is closed and no longer operating, ACS may have some information about the location of the foster care records. If the foster care agency is no longer operating, you can send a written, notarized request with your name, date of birth and last known address/borough by fax to the Records & Compliance Unit at (212) 341-0726 or by mail to The New York City Administration for Children’s Services, Records & Compliance Unit, 150 William Street, 5th Floor, New York, NY 10038.


Request for Letter stating dates of foster care placement:

Contact the ACS Office of Advocacy

150 William Street, 1st Fl., New York, NY 10038

Hours: 9:00 am – 5:00 pm, Monday – Friday

Phone: (212) 676-9421

Incarcerated parents: Collect (212) 619-1309


Request for Adoption Records:

ACS does not have access to adoption records which are sealed by the Court in accordance with Domestic Relations Law §114. Inquiries regarding an individual’s birth family can be handled at the New York State Department of Health Adoption Information Registry. Information regarding adoption subsidy should be directed to the ACS customer service for Post Adoption information at 212 676-2825. The customer service number (automated) addresses families who wish to report a death of an adoptive parent or child, address change, Medicaid issue, direct deposit request, budget letter request or concern regarding payments.


Out of State/Jurisdiction Child Protective Record Request from Out of Jurisdiction/State Child Protective Agencies:

If your Agency currently has an ACTIVE CHILD PROTECTIVE SERVICES investigation, you can send your signed and scanned request on your agency letterhead to the Intake mailbox at FPS.COIP.Intake.Referral@acs.nyc.gov

The letter MUST include the FOLLOWING statement...

“I certify that the records and reports are necessary in order to conduct a child abuse or maltreatment investigation within our jurisdiction of the subject of the report. The records and reports shall be used only for purposes of conducting such investigation and will not be redisclosed to any other person or agency.”

If this statement is NOT accurate do not include it in your letter however under New York Social Services Law §422(4)(A)(s) we will be unable to forward your request to our legal department that provides copies of child protective investigations.

The Fire Department of the City of New York commonly provides access to the records to the public consistent with Federal, State and NYC laws. Below are instructions for obtaining commonly requested records by Mail, In-Person, Online Self-Service, or Online through OpenRecords/FOIL, along with forms that are needed to complete the process. Records requests that require fees must include a check or money order for the applicable fees payable to 'NYC Fire Department' (no cash accepted).
NOTE: Do NOT send money to the FDNY for fees totaling less than $5.00. The FDNY does not accept checks or money orders for less than $5.00.

PLEASE BE ADVISED: The following are NOT records maintained by the New York City Fire Department.

  1. Asbestos/Lead-based Paint/Certificates of Occupancy – contact the NYC Department of Buildings (DOB) or the NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP)

    2. If you seek records regarding asbestos, abatement, and permits, please submit your records request directly to the NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) via the OpenRecords drop down. Records pertaining to asbestos are not maintained by the FDNY.

    Asbestos & Abatement Permit - Buildings (nyc.gov)

    Asbestos Abatement - DEP (nyc.gov)

  2. Elevators/Fire Escapes – contact the NYC Department of Buildings (DOB)

    3. If you seek records regarding elevators and/or fire escapes, please submit your request directly to the NYC Department of Buildings (DOB) via the OpenRecords dropdown. Elevator or fire escape complaints, inspections, incidents, testing, applications are not categories of records maintained by the FDNY.

    • If you believe there is a record of a violation or summons at a specific building in relation to an elevator or fire escape, follow the instructions for Requesting a Copy of a Violation.
    • If a medical emergency occurred in relation to a fire escape or elevator, follow the instructions for requesting an Ambulance Call Report/Pre-Hospital Care Report (ACR), a 911 Call Report/CAD, or Fire Incident Report
  3. Fire Hydrants – contact the NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP)

    4. If you seek records regarding fire hydrants, please submit your records request directly to the NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) via the OpenRecords drop down. Records pertaining to fire hydrant use, permits, and maintenance, etc. are not maintained by the FDNY.

    • In addition, you may request a fire hydrant: 1) lock, 2) lock removal 3) spray cap for recreational use, 4) installation, 5) removal, or 6) relocation by contacting NYC 311 online at Fire Hydrant Request · NYC311.
  4. Manhole Covers – contact 311 or the NYC Department of Transportation (DOT)

    5. If you seek records regarding manhole covers, please submit your records request directly to the NYC Department of Transportation (NYC DOT) via the OpenRecords drop down. Records pertaining to manhole covers are not maintained by the FDNY.

    • For manhole cover complaints please visit: Manhole Cover Complaint · NYC311.
    • For other manhole cover issues please contact the New York City Department of Transportation customer service NYC DOT - Customer Service.
  5. Non-New York City Location – contact the emergency responder service for the corresponding municipality outside of the five boroughs of New York City

    6. The FDNY only responds to emergencies and calls within the five boroughs of New York City (i.e., Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn, Staten Island, and Queens). If the incident location provided within the request is not within the five boroughs, it is not within the jurisdiction of the FDNY. You will need to submit your request directly to the fire department or emergency responder service for that municipality.

  6. Police Reports – contact the NYPD for records related to police response

    7. For arrest reports and records of police response, please submit your records request directly to the New York City Police Department (NYPD). The FDNY is not responsible for maintaining the records of other city agencies.

  7. Private Emergency Medical Services (non-FDNY EMS) – contact the ambulance provider or receiving hospital specified on your ambulance bill

    8. The New York City Fire Department (FDNY) only maintains records of those patients transported by FDNY Emergency Medical Service (EMS) personnel. The FDNY DOES NOT possess and/or maintain records regarding patients transported by voluntary or private hospital ambulance providers. For records regarding medical treatment through a private service, please submit your request directly to that ambulance provider or receiving hospital. View your ambulance bill to determine your service provider.

  8. Septic Systems – contact the NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) or the Department of Buildings (DOB)

    9. If you seek records regarding septic systems, please submit your records request directly to the NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) via the OpenRecords drop down. Records pertaining to sewers, private drains, septic systems, or approved outlets, etc. are not maintained by the FDNY.

    • For water and sewer forms, information on sewer certifications and permits, and investigations please visit: Sewer Connections - DEP (nyc.gov).
    • For house connections, contact the DOB’s House Connection Unit at https://www.nyc.gov/site/buildings/safety/house-connections.page.

Click the categories above for information on submitting requests for those records.

NOTE: The FDNY is not responsible for maintaining the records of other agencies or outside municipalities.

FOIL and Public Records Requests

The following categories of records can be obtained through Self-Service Online (via FDNY Business), the FDNY Public Records Unit, and/or the FDNY Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) Unit.

    IN-PERSON ONLY (via the Public Records window)

  1. (1) Building/Floor Plans

    2. SELF-SERVICE RECORDS (through FDNY Business)

  2. (2) Ambulance Call Report/Pre-Hospital Care Report (ACR/PCR)
  3. (3) Copy of a Violation (Summons, Notice of Violation, or Violation Order) - self-service lookup for active violations - AFTER 09/07/2021
  4. (4) Violation Special Report - self-service lookup for active violations AFTER 09/07/2021
  5. (5) Fuel Tank Special Report/Environmental Assessment Report
  6. (6) Letter of Approval
  7. (7) Letter of Defect/Notice of Defect
  8. (8) Certificate of Correction (CCR)
  9. (9) Technology Management (TM) - online only

    10. PUBLIC RECORDS UNIT

  10. (10) Ambulance Call Report/Pre-Hospital Care Report (ACR/PCR)
  11. (11) Copy of a Violation (Summons, Notice of Violation, or Violation Order) - records must be located by Public Records unit staff for violations occurring BEFORE 09/07/2021
  12. (12) Violation Special Report - records must be located by Public Records unit staff for violations occurring BEFORE 09/07/2021
  13. (13) Fuel Tank Special Report/Environmental Assessment Report

    14. FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAW (FOIL) UNIT

  14. (14) 911 Call Report (CAD) (NOT Ambulance Call Report/Pre-Hospital Care Report)
  15. (15) Fire Incident Report (NOT Fire Marshal Investigation Report)
  16. (16) Fire Marshal Face Sheet (Cause of Fire Only)
  17. (17) Full Fire Marshal Report
  18. (18) Multi-Part Request
  19. (19) Other Request

IN-PERSON ONLY (via the Public Records window)

For building/floor plans and other in-person record requests please visit the FDNY Public Records window at:

9 MetroTech Center - First Floor

Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201

Use the FLATBUSH AVENUE ENTRANCE

Hours of Operation: Monday - Friday 8:00am to 2:30pm (except Holidays)

Telephone: (718) 999-2681

Email: PublicRecordsUnit@fdny.nyc.gov


(1) Building/Floor Plans

PLEASE BE ADVISED: Requests for building and floor plans MUST be submitted to the New York City Fire Department (FDNY) in person. To maintain the health, safety, welfare, and security of the general public, these records can ONLY be obtained in-person.

Please bring:

  1. a signed letter of authorization from the building owner/management company which includes the account number and bears your name (i.e., authorizing your access to the records) AND
  2. a valid photo ID/driver’s license/state ID to the FDNY Public Records Unit located at 9 MetroTech Center, 1st Floor (Flatbush extension side of the building), Brooklyn, NY 11201.

SELF-SERVICE RECORDS (through FDNY Business with assistance from the Public Records Unit)

Please follow instructions and use the links below.

(2) Ambulance Call Report/Pre-Hospital Care Report (ACR)

  • PLEASE BE ADVISED: To comply with the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) privacy requirement, ACR reports require proof of identity and review of documentation. These records cannot be obtained through FOIL/OpenRecords.
  • ACR reports can be received by: (i) Mail, (ii) In-Person, or (iii) online via email (through myPatientEncounters).
  • To request records in electronic format (via email), visit: myPatientEncounters.
  • Click here for website specific instructions: Hardware, Software and Connectivity Guide (nyc.gov).
  • For further instructions on obtaining ACRs and to get the request form for in-person pickup or mail, click here: public-record-ambulance-call-report.pdf (nyc.gov).

To obtain the following records, (3) through (9) below, please visit the FDNY Business page at fdny-business (nyc.gov) and/or follow the instructions below. To view all instructions and information on the FDNY Business website please scroll to the bottom of each webpage.

(3) Copy of a Violation (Summons, Notice of Violation, or Violation Order) AFTER 09/07/2021

  • To lookup active violations please visit violations (nyc.gov).
  • You can also access the FDNY Business portal directly by using the following link: Accela Citizen Access (fdnycloud.org). *Use Microsoft Edge browser or FireFox
  • For more information, including the detailed FDNY Business User Guide which covers how to create an account, please visit the FDNY Business page at: fdny-business (nyc.gov).

(4) Violation Special Report - AFTER 09/07/2021

  • To lookup active violations, follow the instructions for (3) Copy of a Violation above.

(5) Fuel Tank Special Report/Environmental Assessment Report

  • Follow the instructions for (3) Copy of a Violation above.
  • If no tank information is listed, there are no active or current voided tank records on file.
    • C – Tanks
    • D or E – Underground Gasoline
    • R – Aerosol Motor Oil Generators
  • For further inquiries regarding bulk storage (soil, leaks, hazardous materials, analytical data, etc.), visit the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) at: Bulk Storage - NYDEC.

(6) Letter of Approval

  • EFFECTIVE 09/07/2021, Permits and Letters of Approval are only available via email.
  • For instructions on how to view a Permit or obtain a Letter of Approval, visit the FDNY Business page at: permits (nyc.gov).

(7) Letter of Defect/Notice of Defect

  • For information please visit the FDNY Business page at fdny-business (nyc.gov).

(8) Certificate of Correction (CCR)

  • Certificate of Correction requests must be filed online. Email requests are no longer accepted.
  • To obtain a Certificate of Correction visit the FDNY Business page at: violations (nyc.gov).

(9) Technology Management (TM)

  • All TM applications and amendments must be filed online. They are no longer accepted via US mail, email, or in-person.
  • For information, please visit the FDNY Business page at plan-tm (nyc.gov).

For further assistance obtaining records (2) through (7) detailed above, contact the Public Records Unit at the appropriate email address provided below:

PublicRecordsUnit@fdny.nyc.gov
(2) Ambulance Call Report/Pre-Hospital Care Report (ACR)

VioCopy@fdny.nyc.gov
(3) Copy of a Violation (Summons, Notice of Violation, or Violation Order)
(7) Letter of Defect/Notice of Defect

BuildingProfile@fdny.nyc.gov
(4) Violation Special Report
(5) Fuel Tank Special Report/Environmental Assessment Report

LOACopy@fdny.nyc.gov
(6) Letter of Approval

FDNY PUBLIC RECORDS UNIT

9 MetroTech Center - First Floor

Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201

Use the FLATBUSH AVENUE ENTRANCE

Hours of Operation: Monday - Friday 8:00am to 2:30pm (except Holidays)

Telephone: (718) 999-2681

Email: PublicRecordsUnit@fdny.nyc.gov


TAKE NOTE: The Public Records unit can only lookup ACTIVE violations. Once a violation is cured it is no longer active. Therefore, the information will not be listed in the database.

(10) Ambulance Call Report/Pre-Hospital Care Report (ACR/PCR)

  • PLEASE BE ADVISED: To comply with the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) privacy requirement, ACR reports require proof of identity and review of documentation. These records cannot be obtained through FOIL/OpenRecords.
  • ACR reports can be received by: (i) Mail, (ii) In-Person, or (iii) online via email (through myPatientEncounters).
  • For instructions on obtaining ACRs and to get the request form for in-person pickup or mail, click here: public-record-ambulance-call-report.pdf (nyc.gov).
  • For further assistance contact the Public Records Unit at: PublicRecordsUnit@fdny.nyc.gov.

(11) Copy of a Violation (Summons, Notice of Violation, or Violation Order) - BEFORE 09/07/2021

  • For copies of older violations, or if you are unable to obtain the record through self-service, email the Public Records Unit at VioCopy@fdny.nyc.gov to have the Unit locate the record for you.
  • Records before 09/07/2021 are not available through the self-service FDNY Business portal.

(12) Violation Special Report - BEFORE 09/07/2021

  • For copies of older violations, or if you are unable to obtain the record through self-service, email the Public Records Unit at BuildingProfile@fdny.nyc.gov to have the Unit locate the records for you.
  • Building reports before 09/07/2021 are not available through the self-service FDNY Business portal.

(13) Fuel Tank Special Report/Environmental Assessment Report

  • For fuel tank records, or if you are unable to obtain the record through self-service, email the Public Records Unit at BuildingProfile@fdny.nyc.gov to have the Unit locate the records for you.
  • If no tank information is listed, there are no active or current voided tank records on file.
  • For further inquiries regarding bulk storage (soil, leaks, hazardous materials, analytical data, etc.), visit the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation (DEC) at: Bulk Storage - NYDEC.

FDNY FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAW (FOIL) UNIT

Telephone: (718) 999-0293

PLEASE BE ADVISED:

  1. The following records requests are no longer processed as FOIL requests:
    1. (a) Copy of a Violation (Summons, Notice of Violation, & Violation Order),
    2. (b) Violation Special Report,
    3. (c) Fuel Tank Special Report/Environmental Assessment Report,
    4. (d) Letter of Approval, and
    5. (e) Letter of Defect

    Follow the instructions under Self-Service and the Public Records Unit (above) to access these records.


  2. ALL Ambulance Call Report (ACR) requests submitted through FOIL/OpenRecords will be denied. In order to comply with HIPAA requirements, follow the instructions for Self-Service Records above to obtain your ACR.

  3. For the safety and security of the general public, building and floor plan records requests are only fulfilled in-person by the Public Records Unit. Building and floor plan requests will NOT be processed through FOIL. Please follow the FDNY in-person submission protocol described under the In-Person Only section above.

  4. NOTE: Records requested through OpenRecords/FOIL are subject to redactions or withholding pursuant to Public Officers Law §87(2)(a) – (i)
    • To comply with federal and state privacy laws, personally identifiable information (PII) and protected health information (PHI) will not be released to a 3rd party without express written consent of the individual/patient or, in the case of a deceased individual, express written consent of the decedent's family/executor of the estate. For Letters of Administration please visit the Surrogate’s Court. New York City Surrogate's Courts - N.Y. State Courts (nycourts.gov)
    • In the absence of proof of identity (for self) or express authorization (for 3rd party), a particularized 'so-ordered' or administrative subpoena with notification to the subject and/or qualified protective order may be required.

Choose from the Request Type dropdown list to request records from any of the categories below.

(14) 911 Call Report (CAD) (NOT Ambulance Call Report/Pre-Hospital Care Report)

NOTE: To comply with HIPAA and privacy laws, in order to receive unredacted CADs, you must submit proof of identity, an authorization of release, proof of phone number, and/or other supporting documentation to the FOIL Unit.

  • You will be provided with the contact information to send your supporting documentation once your request is created.
  • PLEASE DO NOT UPLOAD SENSITIVE DOCUMENTS TO THE OPENRECORDS PORTAL.

(15) Fire Incident Report (NOT Fire Marshal Investigation Report)

  • NOTE: ALL Fire Incident Reports (whether requested in-person or online) are now processed through the FOIL Unit and reviewed for redactions pursuant to federal and state HIPAA and privacy laws.
  • Due to the EXTREME HIGH VOLUME of Fire Incident Report requests received weekly and the need for review, calls or emails to the FOIL Unit to expedite individual requests will not be granted unless more than 20 business days have passed.
  • FURTHER NOTE: Out of fairness to all that have experienced a fire or medical event, Incident Reports are processed in the order received.
  • The FDNY will not possess a Fire Incident Report for an incident the agency did not respond to. In those instances, follow the instructions for Private Emergency Medical Services or Non-New York City Location at the top of the page.

(16) Fire Marshal Face Sheet (Cause of Fire Only)

  • The Fire Marshal Face Sheet is a summary of the full Fire Marshal Investigation Report and contains the cause of the fire.
  • The Fire Marshal Face Sheet is automatically included with the full Fire Marshal Investigation Report.
  • For the Face Sheet to be released the investigation must be complete.

(17) Full Fire Marshal Report

  • NOTE: Fire Marshal investigations cannot be expedited. Thus, until the investigation is concluded the report will remain unavailable.
  • You will be provided with a timeframe to expect your records and will be notified of any need to extend the response time.

(18) Multi-Part Request

  • For requests consisting of multiple items or multiple categories of requests (even if listed individually on this page), please choose this option.

(19) Other Request

  • For records requests not covered elsewhere on this page or not covered by FDNY Business, fdny-business (nyc.gov), please choose this option.

NYC Office of Technology and Innovation
Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings

specific_request_instructions.text:
FOIL requests often take 25 days or more to process. You might not have to wait that long. Visit the Data / Transparency page, https://www1.nyc.gov/site/oath/about/data-transparency.page , or use the links below to view the data and informational resources OATH has made available to the public. You will also find information on how you can make a request for records directly with the Clerk’s Office rather than having to file a formal FOIL request. The Clerk’s Office can quickly provide respondents or their representatives with information regarding summonses, bills, affidavits, hearing recordings, and more.

Obtain Records

Summonses

To get a copy of a summons, go to OATH’s Online Summons Finder, http://a820-ecbticketfinder.nyc.gov/searchHome.action . Note: Summons Finder currently does not have summonses issued by DCA, TLC or certain summonses issued by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, such as restaurant summonses.

Bills or Invoices

To get a bill or invoice of outstanding penalties, contact the Clerk’s Office using this online form, https://www1.nyc.gov/site/oath/clerks-office/email-the-clerks-office.page , and select Penalty/Payment Question on the “Message Topic” drop down menu at the top of the form. If your request is related to renewal of a license, you must appear at an OATH Hearings Center, https://www1.nyc.gov/site/oath/hearings/hearing-in-person.page .

Trials Division Decisions or Hearings Division Appeals Decisions

Search for Trials Division decisions or Hearings Division appeals decisions in the New York Law School CityAdmin Online Library, https://www.nyls.edu/cityadmin/ . If searching for Hearings Division appeals decisions, be sure to select the boxes for OATH Hearings and ECB Appeals before you submit your search to get the best search results. If you are searching using a summons number and your search is unsuccessful, enter the summons number again but with a space between every third digit (ex. 123 456 789X).

Additional Information about Summonses

The OATH Hearings Division Case Status dataset, https://data.cityofnewyork.us/City-Government/OATH-Hearings-Division-Case-Status/jz4z-kudi , has information about the infraction charged, decision outcome, penalties imposed, payments, and other status information relating to a case. The summonses listed in this dataset are issued and filed at the OATH Hearings Division by City enforcement agencies. The dataset can be searched in numerous and various ways including but not limited to searches by name, address and summons number. The dataset can also be filtered by creating various search parameters and all data can exported into excel spreadsheets or other types of electronic files.

If you are the Respondent or are authorized by the Respondent:

Hearings Division Case Records

If you are the person named as the Respondent on a summons or authorized by the Respondent, to get your Hearings Division case records (other than summonses), contact the Clerk’s Office using this online form, https://www1.nyc.gov/site/oath/about/records-request.page , and select Request Documents on the “Message Topic” drop down list at the top of the form.

Audio Recordings

If you are the person named as the Respondent on a summons or authorized by the Respondent, to get an audio recording of a hearing when you are not appealing your case, contact the Clerk’s Office using this online form, https://www1.nyc.gov/site/oath/about/records-request.page , and select Request Audio Recordings on the “Message Topic” drop down menu at the top of the form.

To get an audio recording of a hearing because you are filing an appeal, use the One-Click Appeals Form, https://www1.nyc.gov/site/oath/hearings/one-click-appeals-form.page , and select Respondent’s Extension Request and option to request audio of hearing on the “Request Type” drop down menu at the top of the form.

If you are not the Respondent or you are not authorized by the Respondent:

If you need to request documents or audio recordings and you are not the Respondent or authorized by the Respondent to make the request, you must file your request under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL). Learn how to file a FOIL Request, https://www1.nyc.gov/site/oath/about/foil-request.page , for records from OATH.

Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) Requests

Pursuant to 43 RCNY, Section 1-08

If you are requesting records that have been sealed, please submit a completed Designation of Agency for Access to Sealed Records Pursuant to NYCPL 160.50[1][d].

Procedures for Requesting or Inspecting Records

  • All FOIL requests must be made in writing and should include sufficient identifying information, such as the nature, content, and date of the record. It must reasonably describe the record in compliance with the New York State Freedom of Information Law. No particular form or format is required.
  • If you are requesting records that have been sealed, please submit a completed Designation of Agency for Access to Sealed Records Pursuant to NYCPL 160.50[1][d].
  • If you are requesting records on behalf of another person, please provide a notarized nonmedical release signed by that person authorizing you to receive the records on their behalf. Please be advised that the Department of Correction cannot accept a HIPAA or other medical records release form.
  • The Department of Correction does not maintain or possess person in custody medical records. If you are seeking medical records, please e-mail CHSMedicalRecords@nychhc.org or contact:

    CHS Medical Records Unit
    NYC Health and Hospitals Corporation
    Correctional Health Services, Medical Records
    49-09 19th Avenue
    Astoria, NY 11105
    Telephone 646-614-0100
    Fax: 347-774-8153

  • Records to be disclosed under the New York State Freedom of Information Law can be made available for public inspection and copying upon appointment on weekdays, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.
  • All Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) requests to the New York City Department of Correction should be submitted via NYC OpenRecords (nyc.gov/openrecords). Select 'Request a Record' and choose 'Department of Correction (DOC)' from the agency drop down menu.

    Mail
    Peter L. Faherty, Esq.
    Records Access Officer
    New York City Department of Correction
    Legal Division
    75-20 Astoria Blvd
    East Elmhurst, New York 11370

Procedure for Appeals

If you are denied access to a record in response to a FOIL request, you may appeal the denial in writing to Charlotte Owens, Esq., Records Appeals Officer, at the address listed above within thirty (30) days of receiving the FOIL response or via e-mail to FOIL.Appeals@doc.nyc.gov.

Copying Fees
The fees for copying records are
a. 25 cents per page, or
b. actual costs of reproduction

For information or assistance with services for older adults, including caregiver services, please call Aging Connect, NYC Department for the Aging’s information and referral contact center, at 212-244-6469. You may also submit an inquiry online at: https://www.nyc.gov/site/dfta/about/contact-aging-connect.page.


Requests for employment records of current and/or former NYC Department for the Aging employees should be directed to the NYC Department for the Aging’s Office of Human Resources at: benefitsleave@aging.nyc.gov.


Requests related to police reports, arrest records, criminal complaints, or other criminal records should be directed to the New York City Police Department (NYPD) by selecting “NYPD” in the Agency drop-down menu above.

specific_request_instructions.text:
Requests for Payroll/Employment records should be directed to:
 Director Payroll & Benefits Division
 90 Church Street, 12th Floor
 New York, NY 10007

Requests for Medical Records should be directed to:
 Medical Division
 1 Lefrak City Plaza, 16th Floor
 59-17 Junction Blvd.
 Corona, NY 11368

Criminal History/Background Checks:
Requests for Criminal History/Background checks, should be directed to the NYS Division of Criminal Justice Services website:
http://www.criminaljustice.ny.gov/ojis/recordreview.htm

You can also submit a request in writing to:
 New York State Division of Criminal Justice Services
 80 S Swan Street
 Albany, NY 12210

Collision Reports:
Requestors seeking Collision Reports taken by the New York City Police Department (NYPD) before September 30, 2016 should access the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles website:
http://dmv.ny.gov/get-accident-report

You can also submit a request in writing to:
 NYSDMV, MV-198 C Processing
 6 Empire State Plaza
 Albany, NY 12228

Requestors seeking Collision Reports taken by the New York City Police Department (NYPD) after September 30, 2016 should access the NYPD's Collision Report website:
https://collisionreport.nypdonline.org/

Article 6 of the New York State Public Officers Law (FOIL) allows the public to submit written requests for access to Department of Transportation (DOT) records.

If you are seeking documents concerning subway or bus service, please see our website at http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/html/ferrybus/ferrybus.shtml, which states that "DOT is not responsible for New York City subway or bus service. The MTA operates the subway system, issues MetroCards, and operates the Metro-North and Long Island Railroads."

Before making your request for DOT records, check if the information you are looking for is already available to the public.

  • Search DOT street works permits
  • Find information about Alternate Side Parking
  • Check parking regulations throughout the city
  • Find other DOT data, including on traffic advisories, bicycles, Staten Island Ferry, parking, low bridges, trucks and street network changes
  • Check NYC OpenData for data from throughout city government

Some tips for a successful FOIL records search:

  • Be specific as to the records requested. Indicate the date or date range of records requested. If a request is location based, describe the location either as an address, an intersection or a block
  • The request must only be for records and not a question requiring an answer
  • Request only the records that you want
Cost

DOT charges 25¢ per page of paper documents returned. This fee covers photocopying and must be paid before documents will be sent out.

In the “Request Description” box, please describe with as much specificity as possible the record(s) you are requesting. Include, as applicable, the following information:
  • Project name
  • Address
  • Borough(s)
  • Block numbers(s)
  • Lot number(s)
  • CP or ULURP number(s)
  • CEQR number(s)
  • Relevant dates
  • Type of record(s)
Please note: Broadly worded requests seeking “any” or “all” records related to a subject matter have the potential to implicate hundreds if not thousands of records, including emails. Requests for emails require an extensive search, and a determination regarding such a broad request typically takes a minimum of sixty (60) business days. If making a request for emails, when possible, the specific sender(s) and recipient(s) should be identified, as well as specific date ranges.

See more information about the Department's FOIL procedures.

specific_request_instructions.text:
This page is for FOIL requests for records from the New York County District Attorney’s Office (Manhattan DA) only. If you are looking for records regarding cases prosecuted in Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island or the Bronx, please go to the respective websites for the District Attorney’s Offices in each of those counties.

Certificates of Disposition: For a Certificate of Disposition for a criminal case, or other New York County Court records, please reach out to the Central Clerk’s Office at 100 Centre Street, Room 1000, New York, NY 10013, 646-386-4000.

Case Records: If you are seeking the New York County District Attorney’s Office’s records for a case, please include the docket or indictment number, or if you do not have that information, the defendant’s name and the approximate date of arrest.

Sealed Cases: If you are seeking records of a case that was dismissed, or ended by acquittal, that case has most likely been sealed pursuant to Criminal Procedure Law (CPL) 160.50 and you must attach either a completed Designation of Agency for Access to Sealed Records Pursuant to CPL 160.50[1][d], signed by the defendant in the case, or provide a court order unsealing the case.

If you are seeking records of a case that concluded with a conviction by a violation or traffic infraction, that case may have been sealed pursuant to CPL § 160.55 and you must attach either a completed Designation of Agency for Access to Sealed Records Pursuant to CPL 160.55[1][d], signed by the defendant in the case, or provide a court order unsealing the case.

Medical Records: If you are seeking medical records from a case file, to protect the privacy of the persons whose medical records you seek, it may be necessary to attach a signed and notarized waiver from that person. Medical records will not be delivered through OpenRecords.

Cases Involving Sex Crimes: If you are seeking records that might identify the victim of a sex crime, you must include a signed and notarized waiver from that victim under Civil Rights Law (CRL) 50-b(1), or a court order. These records will not be delivered through OpenRecords.

Body-Worn Camera Videos: Body-worn camera footage requires a minimum of four months for review and redaction once the requested video has been located. For footage of homicides or arrests within the past five years, you may wish to submit your request directly to the New York City Police Department (NYPD), to expedite the process. Requests can be submitted to NYPD through the OpenRecords portal by selecting NYPD from the dropdown menu.

Any records to which access is granted will be redacted on privacy and other grounds.

Additional information regarding costs and appeals can be found here.
